PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 363, 314]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 279, 905, 295]]<|/det|> 9702/31 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 300, 905, 315]]<|/det|> October/November 2017 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 320, 905, 335]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 355]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 584, 375]]<|/det|> Additional Materials: As listed in the Confidential Instructions. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|> ## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 432]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 320, 447]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 504, 462]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 477]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 476, 380, 491]]<|/det|> DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 502, 273, 517]]<|/det|> Answer both questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 516, 780, 532]]<|/det|> You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of one hour for each question. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 531, 905, 560]]<|/det|> You are expected to record all your observations as soon as these observations are made, and to plan the presentation of the records so that it is not necessary to make a fair copy of them. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 559, 740, 574]]<|/det|> You are reminded of the need for good English and clear presentation in your answers. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 585, 358, 600]]<|/det|> Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 599, 767, 615]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 624, 806, 641]]<|/det|> Additional answer paper and graph paper should be used only if it becomes necessary to do so. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 604, 666]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 665, 759, 681]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[680, 720, 905, 850]]<|/det|>
For Examiner's Use
1
2
Total

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 72, 714, 89]]<|/det|>
**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 103, 96, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 734, 120]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the motion of a Y-shaped pendulum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 875, 166]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with two pieces of string. The longer piece of string has a loop at each end. The shorter piece of string is attached to a bob.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 507, 198]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 211, 724, 229]]<|/det|>
Attach the shorter string to the middle of the longer string with a knot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 243, 776, 260]]<|/det|>
Ensure the two rods of the clamps are at the same height above the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 274, 542, 291]]<|/det|>
Position the stands approximately \(35 \text{cm}\) apart.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 303, 781, 662]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 673, 509, 691]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 704, 720, 722]]<|/det|>
The angle \(\theta\) is the angle between the two halves of the longer string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 346, 89]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 163, 875, 183]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 196, 144, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 828, 214]]<|/det|>
Pull the bob a short distance towards you. Release the bob. The bob will oscillate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 520, 245]]<|/det|>
Determine the period \(T\) of these oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 380, 876, 399]]<|/det|>
<form>T = ........................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 875, 106]]<|/det|>
Vary the distance between the stands and repeat **(b)** and **(c)** until you have six sets of values of \(\theta\) and \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 792, 139]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\cos \left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)\) and \(T^2\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 165, 945, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>[ ]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 234, 945, 406]]<|/det|>
<form> </form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 473, 875, 492]]<|/det|>
<mark>[10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 504, 143, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 504, 176, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 501, 702, 526]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(T^2\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\cos \left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 504, 875, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 545, 180, 564]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 545, 457, 564]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 545, 875, 564]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 577, 180, 596]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 577, 608, 596]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[494, 792, 871, 812]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 825, 871, 844]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 103, 94, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 875, 137]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the appearance of a line viewed through a jar containing water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 149, 146, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 556, 168]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with an empty glass jar.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 408, 199]]<|/det|>
The thickness of the glass is \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 212, 341, 229]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 317, 876, 338]]<|/det|>
<form>t = .................................................. $cm$ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 146, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 350, 180, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 350, 690, 369]]<|/det|>
The outer diameter of the glass jar is \(d\) as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 380, 556, 603]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 617, 510, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 650, 386, 667]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 710, 875, 729]]<|/det|>
<form>d = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 742, 181, 759]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 742, 583, 759]]<|/det|>
Calculate the inner diameter \(D\) of the jar where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 772, 522, 790]]<|/det|>
\[D = d - 2t.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 866, 871, 884]]<|/det|>
<form>D = .......................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 640, 91]]<|/det|>
Place the jar centrally on the line as shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 100, 720, 214]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 230, 512, 248]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 260, 875, 295]]<|/det|>
Look down on the jar from directly above. The line should appear to pass through the centre of the jar as an unbroken straight line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 307, 181, 325]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 307, 541, 325]]<|/det|>
Move your head backwards and forwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 338, 875, 371]]<|/det|>
When viewed through the water, the line (shown dotted) appears to move as shown in Fig. 2.4.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 381, 710, 495]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 510, 512, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 542, 180, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 542, 752, 560]]<|/det|>
Place the nails on the line either side of the jar as shown in Fig. 2.5.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 570, 720, 686]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 700, 512, 719]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 732, 180, 750]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 732, 875, 765]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 778, 435, 796]]<|/det|>
